pullRequest.title: Use lower tiers in workers based on tier usage
pullRequest.bodyText:
This is a probabilistic approach on when we decide to assign new blocks to lower tiers.
Before we only assign new blocks to lower tiers when tier 0 cannot hold the initial size of a block (by default 1MB or 2MB). This leads to the issue that most blocks are assigned to tier 0 and expand there, refusing to go to lower tiers and freeing space on tier 0. Consequently we have poor utilization in lower tiers.
In this change, we define heuristics that we reject allocation to certain storage dirs if they are close to full. The closer to full it is, the lower the chance that a block is allocated to it (and grows there subsequently). If an allocation is rejected, we move on to trying lower tiers and other storage dirs until we find a place.

nodes.bodyText: These are debug loggings for myself, as I'm testing the PR in various ways. They will be all re-formatted or removed in the end of this work.
The previous code was wrong -- the quest is anyDirInTierWithMedium but here it is checking every tier. Maybe I should fix this in a separate PR.
Please ignore this kind of loggings. They are for my own testing for the moment. They will be removed/formatted at the end of this work.
@gpang Do you think it's possible that we may want a pipeline of Reviewers, instead of having only one?

0.1 is probably too big, like when we have 1TB for a storage dir, that is too far from a block size.
64MB / 1TB = 0.00006. I don't think we want to assign this small decimal to a property.
If a long in bytes make more sense, maybe we can reuse PropertyKey.WORKER_TIERED_STORE_FREE_AHEAD_BYTES?
WORKER_TIERED_STORE_FREE_AHEAD_BYTES is a property we added in 2.3 together with the new CACHE_PROMOTE. I don't think many people use that. I also don't think the property is very useful at the moment. It only controls how much extra we free, on each TieredBlockStore.freeSpace.
@gpang Does this heuristic of probability make sense to you? Do you think instead of a linear function, something quadratic or logistic make more sense to make the probability drop quicker?
Is a unittest possible that can break the old code, and is fixed by the new code?
Instead of a fraction, we could just make it an absolute and configurable value.
Hrmmm, I'm not sure. I don't know what a Reviewer is yet.

I think it makes sense, but we could just make that factor a parameter. Something like
((cutoff - free) / cutoff) ^ alpha

if alpha is 1, it is linear, and the user can adjust the curve by adjusting alpha. Maybe there are nicer curves out there, but this is advanced and may not be necessary.

commit.message: ask for more space at creation time blindly - naive approach
remove tweak on allocation request option
change cutoff from ratio to bytes
correct formula and add preliminary test
update properties and Reviewer unit test
add unit test for the factory
correct tests and update allocator logic

nodes.bodyText: Removed reference to an obsolete class
I think this line will be helpful. We want to know when the SwapRestore tasks are called.
These tests are shared by all Allocator subclasses
See how the probability function works here
I refactored this a bit to remove redundant local variables. I believe the logic are kept the same but please do take an extra look for me. Thanks!

commit.message: need to switch off allocation reviewers for integration tests to pass

nodes.bodyText: I had to add this property because many integration tests on tier storage depend on the deterministic behavior of the Allocator. Another option is to use a NoopReviewer that never rejects an allocation.

+          .setScope(Scope.WORKER)

nodes.bodyText:
Is the namespace for this property correct? Since it seems to only affect the probabilistic reviewer.
Probably not something we need to address in this PR - if users are plugging in their own reviewers, how will they add configuration options?
Will this be extremely verbose?

I feel like having a noop reviewer makes this simpler, by removing this property, and we could even configure the reviewer to behave like the original 2.4, right?
Maybe we call it AcceptingReviewer or something, instead of NOOP.
What do you think?

@@ -0,0 +1,60 @@
+/*
+ * The Alluxio Open Foundation licenses this work under the Apache License, version 2.0
+ * (the "License"). You may not use this work except in compliance with the License, which is
+ * available at www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0
+ *
+ * This software is distributed on an "AS IS" basis, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND,
+ * either express or implied, as more fully set forth in the License.
+ *
+ * See the NOTICE file distributed with this work for information regarding copyright ownership.
+ */
+
+package alluxio.worker.block.reviewer;
+
+import alluxio.annotation.PublicApi;
+import alluxio.conf.PropertyKey;
+import alluxio.conf.ServerConfiguration;
+import alluxio.util.CommonUtils;
+import alluxio.worker.block.allocator.Allocator;
+import alluxio.worker.block.meta.StorageDirView;
+
+/**
+ * Interface for the review policy of allocation decision made by {@link Allocator}.
+ *
+ * Each {@link Allocator} has a Reviewer instance according to the policy definition.
+ * For each block allocation decision, the Reviewer reviews it according to the criteria
+ * defined in the policy.
+ * If the allocation does not meet the criteria, the Reviewer will reject it.
+ * */
+@PublicApi
+public interface Reviewer {
+  /**
+   * Reviews an allocation proposed by the {@link Allocator}.
+   * Returning true means the allocation is accepted.
+   * Returning false meanes the allocation is rejected.
+   *
+   * @param dirView the storage dir that the block is allocated to
+   * @return whether the allocation is accepted
+   * */
+  boolean reviewAllocation(StorageDirView dirView);

nodes.bodyText: Again, this would look simpler if there was a noop or accepting reviewer.

I have some level of concern because each allocator needs to implement the reviewer call independently. Is there some way that the review acceptance and rejection can be implemented once and shared among all allocators?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -53,13 +54,22 @@ public static Allocator create(BlockMetadataView view) {
    * specific location, or {@link BlockStoreLocation#anyTier()} or
    * {@link BlockStoreLocation#anyDirInTier(String)}.
    *
+   * The proposed allocation will be reviewed by a {@link Reviewer}.
+   * The reviewer will check certain aspects of the allocation and may reject the allocation if
+   * it does not meet certain criteria.
+   * The parameter skipReview specifies whether the review should be skipped.
+   * The review should be skipped when we want the behavior of the allocator to be deterministic
+   * and do not want it to be affected by the reviewer.
+   * E.g. We just freed up some space in Alluxio and want the allocation to use the freed space.
+   *
    * @param sessionId the id of session to apply for the block allocation
    * @param blockSize the size of block in bytes
    * @param location the location in block store
    * @param view of the block metadata
+   * @param skipReview whether the review should be skipped

nodes.bodyText: Will this be accessed by different threads? If so, we should use ThreadLocalRandom: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/23396033/random-over-threadlocalrandom
Can this just be a local variable?
maybe for integration tests, we should just set the setting as disabled (or noop reviewer). I think that is in ConfigurationTestUtils

commit.message: resolve comments, add TODO and fix checkstyle

nodes.bodyText: This will help integration tests that use defaults() to avoid the non-deterministic block allocation reviewing

commit.message: add a note of the experimental nature
